div1.p: Reed comments about the family. He writes about the English physicians Durham and Meyers, who are studying yellow fever.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, July 19, 1900
div1.p:
Your sweet
letter of July 13th came, last
evening- Aunt J. Mott's and
the cyclone are a great
pair! Give Sis Mottsey
time, and she will come
Moseying along after a
while! Of course, she is
going to stop long enough
in the wild West to say
howdy to old “Brer Cy-
clone”! She is bound to be
“perlite”! But she'll make
her appearance! Trust her for that:
Have just had a telephone
message from Lawrence.
He is alright, only a little
restless over not hearing
from his Commission- There
seems to have been some
delay in the proceedings
of the Board reaching
Washington - Yesterday,
we had the pleasure of
entertaining Drs Durham
& Meyers, two English phy
sicians, who have been
sent out by the School
of Tropical Medicine at Liverpool, to
study yellow fever. They
are going to Brazil, and
came down to Havana
just to make our
acquaintance & to ascertain
what, if anything, we had
discovered. I enjoyed meet-
ing them very much, as
they were two of the most
typical English men, “don't
you know” that one could
possibly meet. We have
placed our laboratories
at their disposal during
the ten days they will be
in Havana. I send my
sweet little Farmer-lady
a little sweet-pea which grows
in large numbers on the
parade. They look very
pretty in the early morning.
I hope that your row of peas are
doing well and giving many
pretty bouquets for the Centre
table- Don't let the mint-bed
suffer on account of the lack-
of rain, sweet-heart, for
I shall be very thirsty when
I get back. Let Aunt Jane
have the job of keeping it
good and moist! It will be
give her some thing to keep
her mind working, but
don't let her begin to pull
up any weeds! As a weed-
puller, she is first-cousin
to old Brer cyclone! You
know that by experience!
Keep her out of grotto Park!
How I wish that some of the
nice rain that is falling, this
afternoon, could be sprinkling
down on your garden and lawn!
We have splendid showers
nearly every afternoon
and could spare lots of mois-
ture for the drier parts
of the earth- Some of the storms
which pass out of sea, a few
miles from the shore, are
superbly grand! The destroyplay
of the lightning is something
wonderful to see- Certainly
August will be a wet month,
since July has been so dry
with you- It would be too
bad to have our lawn much
injured, but I suppose that
there isn't much danger
of that at this late day.
I do hope that the well won't
give out; but as you have
not mentioned it, I suppose that
it is alright so far-
Thursday morning - July 20th.
How is the sweetest oomsey
in the land this morning? Have
you had a shower - bath yet?
I have just emerged from
mine and it was glorious!
And such a beautiful morn-
ing! Last evening, just before
dinner, we took a drive over
the new military road to
Vedado and were chased home
by a storm coming from
sea-ward. After it passed,
the air was so cooled, that
I had to take off my linen
blouse and put on my blue
one that I came very near not
bringing- Such a night for
sleeping, too! I get into my
little couch at about 9.15 P.M.
and snooze like a top until
6 a.m.- And such an appetite
as I manage to keep up is
really surprising- Am getting
a stomach on me like a St.
Louis Brewer! I do believe
that I have gained 5 lbs,
since I arrived- Of course, I
am dreadfully sun-burned; but
that had taken place before
I had been here a week.
This morning, we will drive
out to Havana in order to
return the call of our Eng-
lish Confre'res, who are stop-
ping at La Florida Hotel.
While there I must go to the
Chief Quartermaster's office
and find out when the next
Transport will leave New
York for Havana- I have heard
that one would leave on July
25th, which would bring it here
on July 30th. If so, she would
probably sail the next day
& reach New York about
August 4th- Wouldn't that
be jolly? I hope that it is
so, as I would like to see
my precious children so soon
again and would also, like to see
what havoc the West Wind
hads played with my fat Far-
mer-lady's ranch. Much love
to dear aunt Jane and to Helen-
Regards to Mr Moore and Jacob-
Take good care of your precious
selves and don't sit up too late or
rise too early! Boo! Boo! Kisses & love
for my darling girls-
